messages: 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:25): By the way, for everyone here who told me about screen  69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e? jgraham?): you 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427k.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:26): (or rather encouraged me to use it, it's not like I hadn't heard about it)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:29): screen is indeed awesome
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:32): if screen could fill my xterm scrollback buffers when i connect to it, rather than handle scrolling itself, i might use it more
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:32): screen is why I have such high IRC uptime
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): i run my shells under emacs, so emacs takes care of it

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:34): i want an irc proxy so i can stay connected, but use an irc client locally. and i want the proxy to feed my client scrollback content too when i connect to it. (up to a reasonable amount, say a day or two. but to include excerpts outside this time period if my nick is mentioned.)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:35): why do you want a local client?
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:35): i am happy with x-chat
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (02:36): although i am quite happy reading my mail in mutt over ssh, a text-based irc client doesn't do anything for me for some reason
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:40): i don't really know how to tell the difference... irc is text
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:44): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: welcome back
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:44): Text-based IRC clients annoy me too.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:44): I don't have a very good reason for this, though.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:45): I tried irssi but didn't feel it was worth it to learn how to use it.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:45): Oh, also I think it only let me use one window for all channels, which is unacceptable.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:45): I have a whole monitor with six channels tiled across it.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:47): also not clear to me what a text-based IRC client is
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:47): means curses-based?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:47): One that runs in a terminal.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:47): Instead of a GUI app.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:47): runs in a terminal, not GUI
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:47): like irssi?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:47): I am a long time GUI IRC client user
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:47): ever since X-Chat back in the day
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:47): now it's 100% Colloquy
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:48): even though Colloquy doesn't quite do everything I would like
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:48): it is usable and pretty to look at
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:48): I recently switched from XChat to Colloquy and been very happy to have made the switch
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:48): also, WebKit
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:48): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:48): plus active developers
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:48): I feel compelled to demonstrate my patriotism
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:48): and responsive developers
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:48): on #colloquy
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:49): I really dislike XChat.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:49): NoOneButMe++
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:49): akempgen++
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:49): Colloquy sounds great, too bad I use Linux.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:49): and of course xenon++++++++++
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:49): I'm pretty sure that's a syntax error.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (02:50): Well, you have an even number of plus signs, so conceivably not, but it's certainly not recommended coding style.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:50): X-Chat feels crufty compared to Colloquy now, though to be fair, lately I have only run it on Windows
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:50): dunno if it feels better in its native habitat

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:51): because of public wifi in several places in Australia blocking port 6667 when I was traveling there, I recently set up screen+irssi and been pretty happy with that too
f2b7346cbd77f01babacf680b0db2b85 (02:51): yoo hoo
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:51): that's me
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:52): I find irssi with the nm.pl and wlstat.pl plugins to be fairly usable
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:53): nm does proper aligning an coloring of nicks
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:53): wlstat.pl gives you a human-readable channel list at the bottom of the screen
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:53): and irssi handles unicode with no problems too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:54): anyway, the trend at http://arewefastyet.com/ is very cool
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:54): I hate Colloquy. I have not been able to figure out how to collect alerted messages so I can read them even if they've escaped from scrollback
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:55): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: yeah, that's annoying
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:55): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: there's also: http://arewefirstyet.com/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:56): ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2: what's this measuring?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:56): where the search terms for JavaScript rank on google
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:56): it also has crazy bugs where it sometimes stops redrawing
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (02:56): as currently if you look for help on JS, the decent documentation is no where to be seen
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:56): and sometimes there are visual artifacts
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:56): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: ping NoOneButMe or akempgen on #colloquy
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:57): I think there's also a bug tracker for Colloquy but can't remember where
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:57): and there's no support for user-configured hyperlinking
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:57): obviously something is wrong with me
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:58): anyway I'm switching to Windows soon, so it doesn't matter
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:58): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: http://colloquy.info?bugs or http://colloquy.info/project/report/1
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:59): wow, 536 bugs
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:59): 536 *active* bugs
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:59): Colloquy needs some more developers‚Ä¶

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:04): http://arewefastyet.com/ makes me wonder whether that point on the Sunspider graph around 370ms or whatever is going to be where all the implementations will end up plateauing for a while
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:04): there is a lot of room for improvement in Colloquy
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:04): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: check out how many active bugs mozilla or webkit have ;-)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: well, yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:05): would be more fair to compare how many bugs Chatzilla has, maybe
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:06): number of open bugs is a function of the size of the QA base, not the engineering base

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:06): about I meant maybe everybody will plateau (or whatever better word) there due to all having basically reached the same limits as far as what performance can be squeezed using the current techniques (that have come around in the last 2 years or whatever)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:07): bug in / out rate are more interesting metrics than open bug level IMO
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (03:07): Number of open bugs is a function of the size of the bug-reporter base.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:07): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I think in the case of Colloquy, it's the same base
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:08): bugzilla.mozilla.org also has bugs for lots of non-Firefox things. Like every time a Mozilla employee requests hardware, that's a bug
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:08): we also have bugs assigned to the legal department
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:08): I don't know who maintains http://arewefastyet.com/ but it might be worthwhile to add Opera to it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:08): Carakan
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (03:09): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, #3 on http://arewefastyet.com/faq.html
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:09): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: <email/>. However, they can't add Carakan easily because no standalone JS shell is available
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:10): jgraham: ‚Üë gsnedders

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:11): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I think we'll probably plateau on Sunspider because we don't think it's a great benchmark at this point, so once we've beaten everybody else the incentive to keep going is low
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:11): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: thanks
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:11): I know JS benchmarks are kind of touchy subject anyway
e75bae18d98f39ddf91395da29c6f1ad (03:12): hey guys, is it possible to check if an image is a part of another image? guessing i'd have to use canvas.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:12): from js?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:12): there's no direct api for it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:12): "part of"?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:12): you could as you say implement it manually using canvas to get the image data

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:12): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: so maybe I shouldn't have brought it up here‚Ä¶ but anyway, it's great to see the progress that chart shows has been made over the last couple months
e75bae18d98f39ddf91395da29c6f1ad (03:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, like one image is a piece of another
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:13): touchy? we do touchy here :-)
e75bae18d98f39ddf91395da29c6f1ad (03:13): for example a picture of a human, the sub-image may just be the head, and i want to check if the whole body contains the head image inside
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:13): I'm not sure what is touchy though
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:13): Like you have a 10x10 image and a 20x20 image and want to see if any 10x10 region of the larger image is precisely identical to the smaller image?
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (03:14): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, thanks!

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:14): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: I suspect there was probably a measurable difference just do the fact of a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 joining the mozilla team :) that's the kind of voodoo he seems to have
e75bae18d98f39ddf91395da29c6f1ad (03:14): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, yes
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (03:14): (and yeah i meant curses based)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:15): he's stuck in Auckland so hasn't had much chance to influence the rest of Mozilla yet :-)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:15): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: you moved already?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:15): I really want to visit Auckland
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:15): you dudes please find me a business reason to travel to Auckland for a visit
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (03:16): yeah just arrived a few weeks ago
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (03:16): come on over :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:17): anyone got an animated GIF with frame numbers? a testcase animated gif?
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (03:19): brb lunch

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:22): Peter`: when I first read "The Chromium Team chose to enable their implementation of the FileSystem API by default. ", it seemed like it implied there was some other WebKit-based implementation of the FileSystem API
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:24): maybe "The Chromium Team recently implemented the FileSystem API, and has now chosen to enable it by default in Chrome." or something would be better
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:24): (or maybe it's just me)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:30): "There is a downside too, as the advocated API is asynchronous, it has a steep learning curve."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:30): in general, do asynchronous APIs have a really steeper learning curve than synchronous ones?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:31): I mean, once you get past the initial step of learning how to program that way at all?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:31): hmm, I guess they do
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:32): [Craig]: Sounds like getImageData and a string search is the best you can do, then
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:32): or at least, they are necessarily always more complicated a bit at least

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (03:42): Mozilla people  042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059): how long should I wait before poking people about checkin-needed not being checked in?
